item.title: IT Departments are Wearin' the Green
item.description: Maintaining IT budgets requires more than just good fortune these days. Many companies are discovering that environmentally friendly practices can save them money. These eco-conscious choices benefit both the planet and their bottom line. One of the first areas to examine is electricity consumption. Power usage can be deceptive because it often occurs in small, unnoticeable increments. Every desktop computer, even when idle, contributes to the overall energy use, measured in watt-hours and kilowatt-hours.

item.title: Cash For Clunker Cell Phones
item.description: While the government’s Cash for Clunkers program for cars might be ending, there’s a similar concept for old electronics. You can get cash for your unwanted devices, including cell phones, laptops, and more! You might not have heard about this, but it’s a great way to earn money from your unused gadgets. From cell phones and laptops to gaming consoles and cameras, many devices have value. Don’t let them sit around collecting dust – see how much they’re worth!

item.title: What To Do With Old Cell Phones and Electronics
item.description: So, you’ve finally upgraded to the latest smartphone but now you’re stuck with your old one. It’s useless without a service plan but you hesitate to get rid of it. Years pass and you stumble upon it again, completely forgotten. It’s just an outdated piece of technology now, the battery long depleted. It’s hard to believe it was once worth hundreds of dollars, leaving you wondering if you could have sold it.

item.title: Samsung Reclaim is Green and Free
item.description: Contrary to what some might believe, being environmentally conscious doesn’t have to break the bank. The Samsung Reclaim M560 for Sprint is a prime example of affordable, eco-friendly technology. This slider phone boasts a full QWERTY keyboard and a vibrant 2.6-inch color display with a resolution of 320 x 240 pixels, capable of displaying over 262,000 colors. Its 2.0-megapixel camera captures high-quality photos and videos suitable for sharing. The Reclaim offers swift 3G connectivity on Sprint’s network, enabling access to services like Sprint TV, Sprint Music Store, and Sprint Video.

item.title: RENEW e-recycling initiative in Singapore grows
item.description: Four major electronics retailers in Singapore – Best Denki, COURTS, Gain City, and Harvey Norman – have partnered with DHL, StarHub, and TES to expand the RENEW e-waste recycling program. By placing RENEW bins in 20 of their stores, these retailers aim to make e-waste recycling more accessible to the public. RENEW, which stands for REcycling the Nation’s Electronic Waste, is a collaborative effort by DHL, StarHub, and TES to promote responsible disposal of electronic devices and ICT equipment.

item.title: Green Your Cell Phone For St. Patrick's Day
item.description: On this St. Patrick’s Day, let’s think about being green in more ways than one! Before the festivities begin, take a few moments to consider how you can help the environment. You might be surprised to learn that millions of old cell phones are discarded yearly. They contain valuable resources like gold – enough to create a significant treasure if they were all collected. Instead of letting these resources go to waste, retrieve that old phone you have lying around, and let’s discover how it can benefit you and the planet.

item.title: Sell Your Free Cell Phone For Cash
item.description: You were wise to get your new, top-of-the-line smartphone for free when you signed up for service. As you search for another discounted or free phone, you might wonder what to do with your old one. Many people keep their old phones, thinking they might be helpful someday.

item.title: Recycle Your Cell Phone To Save A Gorilla
item.description: Recycling old cell phones is beneficial for many reasons, with one significant reason being the protection of the Eastern Lowland Mountain Gorilla in the Democratic Republic of Congo. You might wonder how cell phone usage impacts gorillas in Africa. The answer lies in the interconnected nature of our ecosystem. Cell phones contain various electronic components, including tantalum capacitors. Tantalum, a scarce and valuable metal, enables the miniaturization of capacitors, making them suitable for slim cell phones.

item.title: Cell Phones Piling Up?
item.description: You’ve got a brand new Samsung touch screen phone for Christmas? That’s great! You’ll definitely enjoy it for the next few years. However, what about your old phone? The one you were using just yesterday? It still functions, doesn’t it? Don’t let it become another piece of holiday trash. Instead of feeling sentimental, consider this: Your Christmas tree will be discarded soon, and all that packaging will be recycled. Why not do the same with your old phone?

item.description: The holiday shopping season is here, and with it comes the temptation of new electronics and gadgets. However, it’s also a time to be mindful of spending. item.title: Recycle Your Old iPhone For Cash
item.description: The release of the new iPhone 3G is approaching, and early adopters and tech enthusiasts are eager to get their hands on it. The enhanced features, including faster data speeds, GPS, and expanded application support, make it a significant upgrade. However, the cost of upgrading from the first-generation iPhone is a concern for many. Recent reports suggest that AT&T will offer a trade-in program for iPhones purchased after May 27th in pristine condition.

item.title: Clod Computing Challenges The Cloud
There’s $$$ In E-Waste
item.description: Imagine tossing a $100 bill in the trash. That’s essentially what’s happening when we discard old electronics, or e-waste. While it might not be actual cash, these devices hold significant monetary and material value that often gets overlooked. E-waste isn’t a new issue. It’s been accumulating since the days of bulky radios and TVs. However, the sheer volume of discarded electronics has skyrocketed due to rapid technological advancements and shorter product lifecycles.

item.title: Save the Cell Phone, Save the World
item.description: Cell phones are frequently overlooked as a source of environmental concern, valuable resources, and potential income. While seemingly harmless, these devices contain toxic materials and represent a significant waste problem due to their short lifespans and frequent replacement. A cell phone’s small size and durable exterior might make it seem environmentally benign, but the internal components tell a different story. Lead, cadmium, arsenic, mercury, plastics, and glass are all found within these devices.

item.title: Drowning in a Sea of Cell Phones
item.description: Current estimations show approximately three billion mobile phone users globally, with a billion new devices sold annually. Given that phones are typically replaced every two to three years, this equates to roughly one billion phones becoming obsolete yearly. The question then arises: where do these discarded devices end up? Contrary to assumptions that they are forgotten in drawers, a recent study revealed that only 44% of old phones remain unused at home.

item.title: Green Solution For Old Cell Phones
item.description: Do you secretly collect old cell phones? It seems like everyone has a drawer or basement corner filled with them, all sharing one common trait: they no longer work. The issue with cell phones is that they become outdated long before they stop working. While some might suffer accidental drops or crushing defeats, most could easily be revived with a simple charge and a cellular service plan. However, that’s where the catch lies - the cost of the plans.

Eco-conscious hosting is gaining traction among those seeking environmentally responsible options, and contrary to popular belief, it doesn’t have to break the bank. Dotster provides eco-friendly hosting starting at $5.
